Title: with this inequality $\ln{x}\ln{(1-x)}<\sqrt{x(1-x)}$
Content:
If $0<x<1$, show that
  $$\ln{x}\ln{(1-x)}<\sqrt{x(1-x)}$$ use derivative it's not easy, such 
$$
f(x)=(\ln{x}\ln{(1-x)})^2-x(1-x),
$$
$$
f'(x)=2x-1+\dfrac{2\ln{x}\ln^2{(1-x)}}{x}+\dfrac{2\ln^2{x}\ln{(1-x)}}{x-1}
$$ and we $f(x)=f(1-x)$,then we prove inequality hold in $x\in(0,1/2]$.
can you someone have brief solution?
AcceptedAnswer: For $x\in (0,1)$ $$0<-\log(x)<\frac{1-x^2}{2x}.$$ This follows by estimating the integral $$-\log(x)=\int_x^1\frac{dt}{t}$$ with a trapezoid. Also $\log(x)=2\log\sqrt{x}$ so $$0<-\log(x)<\frac{1-x}{\sqrt{x}}$$ on this interval and your inequality follows.
